ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A great course (it's probably required for you). Even though it is generally required, I would 100% recommend it. The Italian department here has it's sh*t together and is a wonderful group of people to deal with. They take your learning seriously, but not in a miserable mean way. If you even mildly apply yourself, this course will help you reach actual conversational proficiency. It's a great course that's less intense than L1 and L2 but just as learning-filled.
I would definitely recommend ITAL 130 with Prof. Iacovella. If you need a language credit, this is certainly the way to get it.
I already have recommended taking Italian so I thought very highly of this class!
I would say that it is a very interesting and rewarding language, however there is a decent amount of work so be prepared to do work almost daily. Overall I would definitely recommend it.

Good class. Very low workload. 6 tests, weekly essays, and a final, but everything is really straight forward. You watch several Italian films which play a large role in the class. Overall a good course and a great way to help fill the language requirement.
I would recommend ITAL 130 to another student because it strengthened my Italian to a considerable degree and provided an enjoyable classroom environment.

ITAL130 was a very good course. I strongly believe that the professor makes all the difference and Anna Iacovella was fantastic! She is a native Italian, so you actually hear the accent and the overall learning experience is richer. Like ITAL120-ITAL130 you have a weekly Tema that's due on Monday and the final draft that's due on Friday. There are chapter tests every week-and-a-half (workbook chapters are due then too). The textbook for ITAL130 is better than ITAL110-ITAL120 because it presents the grammar all together and all the vocab in complete lists. ITAL130 feels like you're reviewing and solidifying the grammar you learned in ITAL110-ITAL120, so it's nothing really new. The only thing is that you're expected to be reviewing the material, old and new, every night for class the next day.
